Tea algal leaf: Improve shade and ventilation by proper pruning and plucking, reduce humidity through wider spacing and drainage, apply Bordeaux mixture 1% or copper oxychloride 0.25% twice during monsoon, scrape off algal growth manually on thick stems.
Tea anthracnose: Regular light pruning and skiffing for open bush architecture, avoid excess shade, spray copper oxychloride 0.25% or carbendazim 0.1% alternately every 15 days during wet weather, remove and burn severely affected shoots.
Tea bird eye spot: Maintain balanced fertilization (avoid excess nitrogen), regular plucking to remove infected tips, spray copper oxychloride 0.25% or hexaconazole 0.1% at 10–15 day intervals during rainy season, improve drainage and airflow.
Tea brown blight: Apply potassium-rich fertilizer, prune for better light penetration, spray mancozeb 0.25% or copper oxychloride 0.25% during cool humid periods, remove and burn affected twigs.
Tea healthy: Continue regular plucking rounds, balanced NPK (100:50:100 kg/ha) with adequate potash, proper shade regulation (40–60%), good drainage, light pruning every year, monitor for early symptoms, prophylactic copper spray once before and after monsoon.
Tea red leaf spot: Correct phosphorus deficiency with rock phosphate or SSP, avoid water stress, spray copper oxychloride 0.25% preventively during flush periods, maintain soil pH 4.5–5.5.
algal leaf in tea: Increase sunlight penetration by reducing shade trees and pruning, improve air circulation, apply copper-based fungicide (Bordeaux mixture 1%) during high humidity, manual removal of algal mats on main stems.
anthracnose in tea: Light and frequent plucking, avoid deep skiffing during monsoon, spray tridemorph 0.1% or carbendazim + mancozeb alternately every 10–14 days in wet weather, remove infected shoots below infection point.
bird eye spot in tea: Balanced nutrition with reduced nitrogen, regular plucking, prophylactic spray of copper oxychloride 0.25% or propiconazole 0.05% during monsoon, improve field drainage.
brown blight in tea: Avoid stress (drought/poor nutrition), increase potash application, spray mancozeb 0.25% or bitertanol 0.05% during cold humid weather, prune out affected branches.
healthy tea leaf: Maintain optimum plucking table, balanced fertilization, proper shade and drainage, regular light pruning, weekly monitoring, one preventive copper spray before monsoon onset.
red leaf spot in tea: Apply single super phosphate (SSP) or DAP to correct P deficiency, foliar spray of 0.5% DAP if severe, ensure adequate moisture, avoid high pH soils.
